titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. This day, Mr: Harper and Mr: Key the Counsel of Mr: Smith of Ohio appeared, and expecting daily his arrival commenced reading the depositions in the Case— They applied for subpoenas for Messrs: Morrow, Sturges, and Davenport of the House of Representatives, and also for General Wilkinson— But not wanting them immediately this request was postponed. They proceeded to read a great number of depositions; all tending to discredit the character of Elias Glover, untill 4 O’Clock, when the Senate adjourned untill 10. O’Clock to-morrow morning— Several questions were raised and discussed; and we have the promise of a fortnight’s work, before we can expect to finish the business— Mr: & Mrs: Boyd dined and pass’d the Evening here, to take leave of Mrs: Johnson and Adelaide, who are going to-morrow to Baltimore.

2. The Senate met this morning at ten, and agreed to meet during the remainder of the Session at that hour— The Council of Mr: Smith of Ohio, were further heard, and read a great number of depositions, to discredit the testimony of Elias Glover— And a few, with a view to discredit Peter Taylor and Coll: James Taylor— It was almost four O’Clock when the Senate adjourn’d. I pass’d the Evening in my chamber, reading— Mrs: Johnson and Adelaide went this morning to Baltimore.

3. I went with Mrs: Hellen and Catherine Johnson to Georgetown and heard Mr: Sayres— Mr: Hellen went to Bladensburg, and returned in the Evening— Mrs: Hellen and Mrs: Adams pass’d the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s— I went there also at the latter part of the Evening. Mr: Fry was there— I employed great part of the day in writing.

4. Mr: Smith of Ohio this morning, returned, and took his seat by the side of his Counsel— They continued reading their testimony, and after they had concluded, the Depositions sent by Elias Glover in defence of his character were also read— The subject was then postponed untill to-morrow, for the argument of Mr: Smith’s Counsel— The Bill concerning Contracts was debated about two hours without any question taken.— Adjourned after four O’Clock— I dined at Mr: Boyd’s— Mr: T. French and Dr: Weems were there after dinner— I consulted the Dr: upon the complaint in my eyes; which I was apprehensive might be an obstruction in the lachrymal duct; but which he assured me was a relaxation of the gland.— He promised to call to-morrow morning at the Capitol and examine it by day-light.

5. Mr: Smith’s Counsel examined this morning several members of Congress to the characters of their witnesses against Elias Glover— Mr: Key then in an ingenious argument of four hours commenced his defence; immediately after which the Senate adjourned— I received this morning several letters from Boston—one particularly from my brother; hinting a wish for me to do what I have already done.— Spent the Evening at home; writing.

6. Met at half past nine this morning the Committee upon the Chesapeake Message from the President— Messrs: Anderson, Giles, Smith of Maryland and Bradley, are the other members— After some discussion it was agreed that the Chairman Mr: Anderson, and Mr: Giles should confer with the Secretary of State, that there may be an understanding and concert between the measures which may be proposed to Congress, and those which have been taken by the Executive— In Senate, after an examination of Messrs: Russell and Gardenier of the House of Representatives to the characters of several witnesses, Mr: Harper as Counsel for Mr: Smith of Ohio, made a speech of about three hours and a half— He, as well as Mr Key, attacked the principles of the Report of the Committee with great force— He also commented with much ability upon the Testimony, and examined all the points of Evidence, which he thought likely to operate against Mr: Smith— After he finished the consideration of the report was postponed untill to-morrow.— The Bill, which was originally the Treason Bill, now changed into a Bill for the punishment of certain crimes, was finally pass’d, by a majority of 18. to 12.— Mr: and Mrs: Erskine were here about an hour this Evening— General Van Cortlandt and Mr: Verplanck, also spent part of the Evening with the family below; but I was so much engaged, that I was obliged to leave them; and write all the Evening in my own chamber.

7. The consideration of the Report of the Committee, on the Case of Mr: Smith of Ohio, was after some discussion postponed untill to-morrow— Mr: Smith of Maryland offered a resolution to request of the President, certain letters of Matthew Nimmo—this resolution was adopted— The Bill concerning Courts Martial and Courts of Inquiry was debated as in Committee of the whole, and a variety of Amendments proposed— None of them however were adopted, and no question taken on the Bill— Adjourned after 4.— Evening, busy in my chamber.

8. The Case of John Smith of Ohio, was again taken up; and after some discussion how the question should be taken, Mr: Franklin moved that the Senate should take into consideration the Resolution of expulsion with which the Report concludes— This was agreed to, and I made a speech of nearly four hours on the question— I could not do justice to the subject— There is no occasion upon which I feel with so much humiliation the insufficiency of my own powers, as in these elaborate but extemporaneous speeches— I spoke however more successfully than I had a right to expect, and with considerable impression, even where it was unwelcome— Mr: Giles immediately moved that the further consideration of the Resolution should be postponed untill to-morrow; which was done— The Court Martial Bill was then taken up— But it was late, and not much progress was made in its discussion— Adjourned about 4.— S. H. Smith the Editor of the National Intelligencer asked me to give him a copy of my Speech, which I promised him, as near as my recollection would serve— Evening at home; and very hoarse.

9. This morning on the meeting of the Senate, the case of Mr: Smith was immediately taken up, and Mr: Hillhouse in a Speech of about two hours renewed his attacks upon the report of the Committee, and upon my argument of yesterday— He also was very decided in favour of Mr: Smith— His speech would have made little impression— But Mr: Giles in one of the most animated and eloquent Speeches I have ever heard him make, declared himself, not against the principles of the Report, for he expressed his entire concurrence in them, but against the Resolution for expulsion— He argued the cause of Mr: Smith, with all his eloquence, and returned to the charge with increasing warmth untill the last moment— Mr: Pope also made a very strong Speech in Smith’s favour— Mr: Anderson and Mr: Crawford supported me with ability on the other side— The question was taken near 5. O’Clock in the afternoon and the yeas and nays on the Resolution for expulsion stood thus.

As the concurrence of two thirds of the members is necessary to carry a resolution for expulsion, this was lost by a single vote— Mr: Mitchell and Mr Bradley were both absent doubtless intentionally—unwilling to vote on either side.— This is sometimes called bolting, and sometimes flying the course— The Senate immediately adjourned, but Mr: Smith as I heard from General Sumter had already resumed his seat— I did not see him— I went with Genl: Smith of Maryland to the President’s, where we dined— We found Dr: Mitchell there— And he made some sort of apology to Mr: Smith of Maryland, who reminded him of his absence when the question was taken— He said he thought the question would not have been taken to-day— That if he had been there he should have voted for the Resolution— His vote would have carried it— Genl: Smith of Maryland told me, as we were riding to the President’s, that Giles had carried off Pope & Thruston; and that he had taken pains out of doors to bring him over, and Genl: Sumter.— I saw him also endeavouring to influence Mr: Gaillard & Mr: Milledge, whom he urged untill they were displeased— He told me further that Mr: Smith of Tennessee, had the day before yesterday agreed to vote against the Resolution, but that my argument of yesterday had convinced him— I feel so much personally for the man, and his family, that perhaps no issue of this transaction, could have been more agreeable to me. He retains his seat, but his conduct is sufficiently reprobated by the state of the votes— The duty which I have discharged was imposed upon me much against my will, and I have discharged it to the best of my power.— Spent the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s.

10. I went with Mrs: Hellen, and Catherine Johnson to the Capitol, and heard from Mr: M’Cormick a sermon on the dangers of a death-bed repentance— I have heard the same Sermon from him once before— Two or three years since—at Georgetown. The remainder of the day after coming home, I was employed in writing.

11. There was much business dispatched in Senate this day, but very little debate— The Habeas Corpus Bill was postponed untill the next Session— The Bill concerning public Contracts pass’d to the third reading.— The Resolution from the joint Committee, for closing the Session the 25th: of this month, was adopted by both houses— I reached the Capitol this morning, rather later than usual, and found the Senate in Session— The Vice-President had been formally complaining of the President for a mistake which was really his own— The Message of 26. Feby: was read in public, because the Vice-President on receiving it had not noticed the word “confidential,” written on the outside cover— This has been told in the newspapers, and commented on as Evidence of Mr: Clinton’s declining years— He thinks it was designedly done by the President, to ensnare him, and expose him to derision— This Morning he asked Mr: Otis for a certificate that the message was received in Senate without the word “confidential.”—which Otis declining to do, he was much incensed with him, and spoke to the Senate in Anger—concluding by saying that he thought the Executive, would have had more Magnanimity than to have treated him thus— This Scene happened before I took my seat.— Mr: James Smith of New-York called me out of the Senate chamber, and gave me a letter from my nephew John— He is here on some difficulty about settling his Accompts with the War-Department, and wants my assistance— I desired him to call to-morrow.— Mr: Smith of Ohio resumed his seat.

12. I received Instructions from the Legislature of Massachusetts, respecting the Amendment to the Constitution to make the Judges removable by address of the two Houses— I presented them, and on motion they were ordered to be printed & referred to Mr: Tiffin’s Committee— I made report also respecting the Letter, Report & Documents on the subject of roads and Canals from the Secretary of the Treasury; for 1200 copies to be printed— And I offered a Resolution requesting the Secretary of the Treasury to transmit, franked by mail, six copies to each member of Congress, after the close of the session— Both these Resolutions were adopted— I asked leave to bring in the Bill for the relief of A. M’Call and others, which Mr: Bradley opposed with great earnestness. I had no expectation of opposition at this stage, as I have never known any objection made to leave for bringing in a Bill— I did however obtain it, though it will doubtless be to little purpose. The public Contract Bill pass’d 21. to 4.— Mr: Hillhouse read a Dissertation, of nearly two hours in length to introduce several Articles of Amendment, which he proposes for the Constitution of the United States— Senate adjourned before 3.— Mr: James Smith called upon me again, and wished me to interfere in his favour for the settlement of his Accounts with the War Department, which I explicitly, and decidedly declined— He wished me to write for him what he was to say—he would Copy it, and burn what I should write, which might also be without my signature— All this I also declined— But upon his Statement, I advised him to make application personally to the Secretary at War; and I assured him of my willingness to give him all the advice and assistance in my power; consistent with my own duties— Spent with my wife part of the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s.— George 7 years old—

13. A variety of business was done in Senate, but none which occasioned much debate; the Court-Martial Bill, after having once pass’d to a third reading, was again taken up as at the second, and amended; after which it pass’d to the third reading.— After the adjournment, Mr: Anderson’s Committee on the Negotiation Message met, and considered a proposition for authorizing the President to suspend the Embargo, during the recess of Congress, if Circumstances to justify that measure should occur— I submitted a Proposition for prohibiting all commercial intercourse with France, Spain, Holland, and Great-Britain, and repealing the Embargo, with respect to the dominions of all foreign States, not having issued decrees in violation of the Laws of Nations against us— This was rejected. I then proposed that the President should be authorized to suspend the non-importation act as well as the Embargo. This was agreed to.— The Ladies pass’d the Evening at Mrs: Erskine’s.— I had called this morning on the Secretary at War, to present him applications for Offices in the army— The names were on his list.

14th: The Court Martial-Bill was debated at the third reading, and pass’d as amended by a considerable majority— My bill for the relief of Mr: M’Call and others was referr’d to a Committee at the second reading—Mr: Bradley, Mr: Reid and myself— Mr: Dana called me out, from the Senate, and I had a couple of hours of conversation with him, principally respecting certain propositions for the arming of merchant vessels in concert; and for requiring a certain proportion of American citizens, on board of our vessels.— Evening at home— Mr: Buchanan was here, on his return from Virginia.

15. Mr: Crowninshield, a member of the House of Representatives, from Massachusetts, died this morning. Which being communicated to both houses they adjourned at an early hour.— The Committee on the foreign Documents met— At their last meeting Mr: Giles suggested the propriety, of consulting the Secretary of State, for the purpose of harmonizing with the Executive on the principles of the Report to be made— Mr: Anderson the chairman now produced the sketch of a Report ready drawn by Mr: Madison which he had requested might be modified by the Committee so as to make it their own— Mr: Giles observed that Mr: Madison particularly requested that I would revise it, and make any alteration or addition I thought proper— I made one alteration and one addition, to which Mr: Anderson the chairman assented— Mr: Giles hinted to me that the reason why he had proposed applying to Mr: Madison was because he doubted our chairman’s competence to draw up a proper Report on a subject of such delicacy and difficulty— Mr: Anderson and myself agreed upon the Report, to be made to-morrow morning.— Mr: & Mrs: Boyd, dined and pass’d the Evening here— Mr: Johnston, and Mr: Sheldon were also here— Mr: Buchanan was to have gone in the mail Stage, this Night, but it went & left him.

16. The remains of Mr: Crowninshield this morning were sent away to Baltimore— To be transported to Salem— Both houses attended the funeral a short distance on the Baltimore road— They adjourned for that purpose from ten O’Clock untill Noon. The Vice-President took leave of the Senate for the remainder of the Session— Mr: Smith of Maryland was on a second trial chosen President pro Tem; Business was dispatched with great rapidity— There was a debate at the second reading of the Bill authorizing the President on certain contingencies, during the recess to suspend the Embargo; which however pass’d to a third reading— As did my bill for the relief of Joseph Summerl and others; though not without difficulty— Evening at home.— Mr: Buchanan went away this morning.

17. Attended Church at the Capitol and heard Mr: Brown— The attendance was unusually thin— Saw the eldest son of Mr: Parkman, and young Mr: Sears of Boston there— Mr: Giles obtained leave of absence yesterday, and went off this morning.— I received copies of my letter to Mr: Otis—printed from Boston— I also finished writing off my Speech on the case of Mr: Smith of Ohio— Whole day at home, excepting during church time.

18. My bill for the relief of Joseph Summerl and others, pass’d this day in Senate— As did also the Bill authorizing the President to suspend the Embargo— An additional Embargo Bill was also debated at the second reading, & postponed. Mrs: Adams dined at her Sister Boyd’s— I employed the Evening, in reading Mr: Baring’s pamphlet on the Causes, and Consequences of the British Orders of Council of 11. Novr:— Received several letters from home— Of various import.

19. I concluded the perusal of Mr Baring’s pamphlet, in which much of the Statement in my letter to H. G. Otis is confirmed. The Committee on the Post-Office Bill met, and agreed to report an Amendment, to strike out the Section containing all the new Roads— After some debate the bill was postponed in Senate to the first Monday in Decr:— Various other Bills were acted upon— But with very little debate— Evening with Mrs: Adams at Mr: Boyd’s.

20. A number of Bills were pass’d in Senate—chiefly without debate— The Bill additional to the Embargo, pass’d by yeas and nays 21. to 5.— The bill fixing the time for the next meeting of Congress, was likewise agreed to by a large majority— The time fixed is the first Monday in November— Evening at home, writing— Mrs: A. spent it at her sister Boyd’s.

21. We continue to dispatch business so expeditiously that the Senate this day adjourned as early as two O’Clock. Mr: White’s Bill for fitting out the frigates and armed vessels pass’d to a third reading after some debate— I made a Report on the Petition from Boston, for liberty to export certain fish— A number of bills pass’d without debate— After the
adjournment, I went for a short time into the House of Representatives— Evening at home— Mr: Boyd spent it with us below— Mrs: Adams all day quite unwell

22. The bill for manning equipping and fitting out all the armed vessels of the United States pass’d by yeas and nays 22 to 4— A great number of other bills were read; some two or three times—and no debate— In Executive business two nominations were confirmed, and one referred to a Committee— I wrote to Mr: Hall, enclosing a copy of a Report on the Petition from Boston, for permission to export certain dry and pickled fish.— Evening at home— Mrs: Adams and Mrs: Hellen pass’d it at Mrs: Boyd’s.

23. In Senate, the business is dispatched so fast, and received so slowly from the house, that we adjourned this day from about 2 to 5. O’Clock— And soon after meeting then, again adjourned— I dined with the Speaker, Mr: Varnum at his lodgings— There were several members of both houses of Congress— Some lodgers in the house; and others invited guests— Mr: Milledge, & Mr: Robinson—Messrs: Cutts, Jones, Macon, Fisk, Witherall, Findley, and some others.— Mr: Gilman this day spoke to me, with intimations that it was the wish of several gentlemen with whom he had conversed, to bring me forward, in some active and distinguished Station— But that it was wished I would take occasion either in some Speech, or in some written publication to express my Sentiments with respect to the practicability of our present form of Government— As from some of my writings published before I went to Europe, there were persons who thought me inclined to favour a Constitution approaching nearer to the monarchical form— I told him I would reflect upon these suggestions, but my present impressions which I did not think likely to change, were these—I was sworn to support the Constitution of the United States— I would support it with the utmost of my power, and with perfect sincerity— I had during the present Session of Congress, to say nothing of preceding dates, pledged more to support it, in my own opinion, than any other man in the Union— I had sacrificed to it the favour of the party which had placed me in my present Station— I had therefore not only the common Stake of others who support the Administration, but the responsibility of appearing to abandon my own party; and was liable to all the obloquy which such desertion carries with it— My motive for it was, to support the Constitution as I had sworn— I had therefore taken an active part in the public Affairs both foreign and domestic— And to the best of my ability endeavoured to defend it against its enemies external and internal— But I had not set one party at defiance, in this conduct, for the purpose of making myself the instrument of another— That as to my speculative opinions upon the practicability of our present Constitution, I had my doubts, whether in case of a War, it would get along in its present form— I believed it would become, more democratic— With regard to the theory of Government, I had not for many years read over any of the papers written by me and published before I went to Europe; but I was not aware of any one sentiment or opinion contained in them, that I could now retract— That, as to my being brought forward in a conspicuous Station, I certainly did not think it a desirable thing— There was not a place in the gift of the People or of the Executive of the United States or of my own State, for which I had the slightest wish— That to be dismiss’d from the place which I now am in, would doubtless occasion a moment of personal mortification, for which however, my mind was made up; and which would be more than compensated by the advantage of being released from the cares of the public service, at such a time as this— But that as to any thing else, so far as my personal desires were concerned, I would not speak ten words; nor write two lines to be President of the United States— Nor of course to be any thing subordinate to that— He said this was standing on very independent ground indeed— But that for himself he was satisfied there ought to be that Confidence in a Man’s Principles, & integrity, not to require of him any pledge of opinions at-all.— I did not enquire, nor did he tell me with whom he had conversed, or what the object was to which he referr’d as the conspicuous Station of which he spoke in general terms— Mr: Gilman however is the particular friend of Mr: Clinton, as Mr: Giles is of Mr: Madison, with respect to the Presidential Election— And he some time since asked me which of the Departments I should prefer— That of State, or that of the Treasury— I answered him laughingly that I was about as well qualified for the one as for the other— He then said in the same tone; that he thought so too. But he believed the Department of State would suit me best; and when he should be President of the United States, I should have it.— Evening at home— Mrs: Adams at her sister Boyd’s— Who is very unwell.

24. I went to the Capitol to attend Church, but there was no service performed— Returning home I was overtaken by Mr: and Mrs: Erskine, who took me home— Remainder of the day spent in writing; as leisure would permit— Mr: Boyd and Mr: Sheldon—Mr: Goodrich and Mr: Pitken—Mr: Verplanck & Mr: Kirkpatrick all called to see us, and to take leave at the close of the Session.

25. This day closed the First Session of the Tenth Congress; which has been sitting precisely six Months— The day pass’d in the usual hurry and confusion of a closing day— But without the usual differences between the two houses— And it is remarkable that this is the first Session since the Establishment of the Government during which there has not been one instance of a Conference upon disagreeing votes.— There were however many bills this day postponed to the next Session— The Senate adjourned from 1/2 past 3 to 5. O’Clock— After 7. in the Evening, a Bill of five long Sections was sent for the first time from the House— We pass’d it however, with some difficulty— About 9. O’Clock in the Evening the two houses adjourn’d— I dined with Mr: Gilman at Mrs: Beckley’s— Just before the adjournment of the Senate Mr: John Randolph came in, and went round within the body of the House, and took leave of every member present— To Dr: Mitchill and Mr: Gilman he spoke very emphatically, with good wishes for New-York, and the Vice-President.— I wrote an Answer to Dr: Eustis.

26. The greatest part of this day, I spent in packing and preparing for our departure to-morrow morning— Called at the Secretary of State’s Office, to read a part of a dispatch from Mr: Monroe, which was among the confidential papers of the Presidents Message— Mr: Boyd dined with us— Mr: Sheldon and Mr: Fry spent the Evening below.

27. At 6 this morning, I left Mr: Hellen’s house, with my wife and child—Catherine Johnson, and our maid Sarah. We had among our fellow-passengers Mr: Taggart and Mr: Burwell, members of the House of Representatives— But we miss’d Mr: Gilman— We breakfasted as usual at Ross’s— Dined at Spurrier’s— And about 7. in the Evening arrived at Baltimore— The house at Evans’s tavern was full, and Mr: Stewart had engaged lodgings for us at a boarding house on the other side of the Street— A house kept by a french family from St: Domingo, by the name of Lecomte— Mrs: Johnson, who with her daughters Eliza and Adelaide is at Mr: Harper’s, came in immediately after our arrival— They were all going to the play, and Catherine went with them— I went down upon the wharf and engaged a passage for us in one of the Packets which is to sail to-morrow morning.

28. Mrs: Johnson, with Eliza and Adelaide called and took leave of us this morning; and at 9. we embarked on board the Packet President, Captain Ferguson, on the New Line— Mr: White was with us— But Mr: Dana and Mr: Taggart went in the old Line— Both left the wharf at the same time, a few minutes after 9. O’Clock. We had beautiful weather; but very light wind, and much of the time calm. About 9 in the Evening we landed at Cecil-Court-House-Point, and immediately took the Stages for Newcastle.

29. Between 3 and 4. O’Clock this morning we arrived at Newcastle, and immediately embarked in the Packet Telegraph, Captn: Weldon— We were about an hour ahead of the passengers in the other line— But the tide running down the river, and no wind, we were obliged to lay at the wharf untill 8 in the morning— We had another very fine day, but scarcely any wind. We reached the wharf at Philadelphia, about 4. in the afternoon; preceding about five minutes the Packet of the old line. Mr: White left us at Newcastle— Among our fellow-passengers, was a Mr: Dennis, who was very obliging in assisting us in a search for lodgings— We went to four different houses before we could find any, and at last obtained chambers at Mrs: Decharms’s, at N: 190. Market Street. At Mrs: Lawson’s we found Mr: Gilman laid up lame— Having travell’d in the Mail-Stage, which this morning oversat, by which he received a hurt— Mr: Varnum the Speaker of the House was with him— In the Evening I call’d at Mr: Hopkinson’s, where I found company— Mr: Ewing and Mr: S. Nicholas among them— Mrs: Hopkinson is confined to her chamber, having within a few days lost a child of 6 months, with the measles, and three or four others now having the same disease.

30. Mr: M’Call and Mr: Ewing called upon us this morning— I went with Mr: Ewing, and called upon Mr: Dennie. We then went all together and visited the Academy of the fine Arts, where they have a handsome collection of the most celebrated antient Statues, and also a small collection of good pictures— I went out with Mr: Ewing and a Doctor Earle, and dined at a House on the further banks of the Schuylkill river; where I recognized a place which I had visited in the year 1794. as the residence of General Knox— We met there Mr: R. Peters— Two Gentlemen by the name of Biddle, Mr: Curwin, Dr: Chapman, Mr: Markoe and Mr: S. Nicholas— We returned early in the Evening, and cross’d the permanent Bridge to come into the City— Mr: Dennis, and Mr: T. M’Kean were with the Ladies, on our return, and had been with them to walk.— I engaged seats in the Stage for New-York that is to go, Monday Morning.

Day. Untill the Session of Congress closed, it was very regular; and its only exceptionable part, was a degree of application too intense for my powers—most especially for my eyes, which are suffering to an alarming degree— Since the termination of the Session, I have been travelling homewards; of course without any uniformity of employment for my time.
